g.text: P → Q is automatically true when:
These are often the simplest proofs!
When P is false, P → Q is
of the truth value of Q
Show that P is always false:
• Demonstrate P is an empty condition
Successfully shown P is always false?
No - P can be true in some cases
Since P can never be true,
Conclude: P → Q is vacuously true ∎
P can be true, Q can be false
When Q is always true, P → Q is
of the truth value of P
Show that Q is always true:
• Verify Q holds for all valid inputs
Successfully shown Q is always true?
No - Q can be false in some cases
Conclude: P → Q is trivially true ∎
Check both P and Q more carefully
When to Look for Vacuous Proofs:
• P has empty domain or impossible constraints
• P involves division by zero or undefined operations
• P requires satisfying mutually exclusive conditions
Statement: "If x is both even and odd, then x > 100"
Proof: No integer can be both even and odd,
so the hypothesis is always false.
Therefore, the statement is vacuously true ∎
Statement: "If n is an integer, then n² ≥ 0"
Proof: For any real number (including integers),
